title: Nirenberg: Hold city elections in November
text:
Nirenberg: Hold city elections in November Councilman believes voter turnout would improve with unified elections By Cory Smith - VJ, Reporter Posted: 5:57 PM, October 05, 2015 Updated: 6:28 PM, October 05, 2015 More News Headlines Taylor: City to move forward with lawsuit against SAPOA 
SAN ANTONIO - District 8 Councilman Ron Nirenberg announced Monday that he'll lead efforts to move the city's municipal elections to November during even-numbered years. 
Currently, city elections are held in May during odd-numbered years. Nirenberg believes putting municipal elections on the same ballot as federal and state elections will result in higher voter turnout. 
"We know that in cities where they have unified elections, there's much better participation," Nirenberg said. "Frankly, we should all be tired of the fact that really 1 out of 20 registered voters participates in municipal elections." 
Voter turnout was abysmal in the May election despite a handful of hotly contested races, including Ivy Taylor's run-off with Leticia Van de Putte. The marquee matchup and several ballot initiatives could not push turnout past 15 percent. 
Nirenberg said moving the elections to November, when voter awareness is at its peak, would also save money. 
"The more elections we have, the more personnel we have to put out there and fine tuning the equipment. When we have unified elections, it is more efficient on our election department," Nirenberg said. 
The city of Austin recently moved its municipal elections to November, and Nirenberg said the results have been astounding. 
"Their turnout went from 10 percent to 40 percent turnout," Nirenberg said. 
Moving the elections to November would require action from the state legislature and a change to the city's charter. Nirenberg said, were his efforts to succeed, the first unified elections in San Antonio wouldn't take place until 2018 at the earliest. Copyright 2015 by KSAT - All rights reserved.
